(or was it another series).So where do we belong here? OJ Simpson gets drilled by gunmen before his infamous murder trial and still people do not get where this movie is going? There is so much going on and so many cameos from famous folks in the era that even the Queen of England though central to the plot is really a second fiddle here.Ricardo Montoban is a prefect straight man to play the main bad guy who bumbles his way along a step behind Frank Drevin (Neilsen). The roles are so perfect that everyone in the movie shines. Even Reggie Jackson gets treated better here than he did when he introduced Reggie candy bars.The throw away lines in this one are better than a lot of comedy films. I have to wonder if the writers on an inside joke were sticking their tongs out at a public not smart enough to watch Police Squad? Could be

First time I watched The Naked Gun it got me almost enlightened by laughing my best piece off (the only movie I remember where the laugh-o-meter did hit harder is The Life of Brian, of course, one could dare to say). The role of Lt. Frank Drebin was made for Leslie Nielsen like the almighty Conan for Mr. Schwarzenegger. On top, the whole cast is playing fine and obviously having fun and there are lots of funny and even original and remarkable ideas around. What else? Well, this is comedy (almost) in perfection.

reviews.review_title: you have the right to remain in hysterics
reviews.content: Liutenent Frank Drebin (Leslie Neilson) has to foil a plot by Ricardo Montalban to assassinate Queen Elizabeth the second. But c'Mon the plot doesn't really matter. All you need to know is this was a movie version of the "police Squad" show and that it was made by the team of Zucker/Abrahams/Zucker in their heyday. Which means non-stop sight gags and slapstick from beginning to end at breakneck speed with nary a time to catch your breath. This movie is hilarious and for you kids who only know "Scary Movie 3", you have no clue how truly hilarious these guys can be. Rent this, "Airplane" and "Top Secret" for a night of non-stop laughter. You can thank me in the morning.My Grade:B+ DVD Extras: Commentary with David Zucker, Robert Weiss, and Peter Tilden; and Theatrical trailer (it would have been nice if they included deleted or the extended TV scenes) Eye Candy: A random girl's ass in the beginning credits

reviews.review_title: Was it the last great spoof movie?
reviews.content: For a lot of people, this film happened to be the last great parody movie ever made. It seems like right after this movie, the parody genre just got worse and worse. We finally hit rock bottom with "Disaster Movie" ranked as the worst film of all time by the IMDb. Were people just thinking this movie was a tough act to follow? There have been zero spoof movies since that would be considered truly great. If nothing else, we can at least look back at this once great style. I heard "Sausage Party" was technically a spoof, but it still wasn't on the same level as these old ones. Modern spoof movies just have the characters fart and poop all the time, but these ones actually made us laugh.It is kind of weird looking back and seeing OJ in a good movie role. Of course, he does get injured in this movie a lot. This film is great from the very first jokes. I think my favorite part would be when he says, "Bingo!" and finds a Bingo card. This is another movie you have to pay attention to in order to get all the laughs in. I just love how this film escalates in its zaniness. Even if you've seen a compilation of best parts like me, there's still more to love. The madness doesn't even end with the credits. There's this gag where they list every person by labeling them with their dialogue! It actually does make sense, in a really amusing way. The pop culture references are a lot more subtle than other films and it works much better that way.This is what comedy should be. The slapstick is wonderfully timed. Everything comes together so well in this. There's always jokes that build up to each other and best of all, it has a coherent story. They do work hard to make these jokes relevant as to what is going on, not just random interchangeable gags. Even better is that I actually really do care about the main characters in this. I wanted them to get out okay! For all the laughs, there was good emotion here too. I didn't even know this was based on a TV show. I have seen some clips of it and it seems great too! I think the directors eventually split over arguments which is why their films have declined, ending with the worst, "Scary Movie V". While there are still great comedies, we'll never be restored to this level of quality in spoofs right here. May this film and its spirit live on forever! ****

Before the '90s had The Dude from "The Big Lebowski," and before "Borat" used the 2000s to roll around naked on a bed with his corpulent best pal, there was "The Naked Gun" and the legendary Frank Drebin, played with the straightest straight-face ever by the remarkable Leslie Nielsen. "The Naked Gun" comes from the ancestory.com chart first hinted at by "The Kentucky Fried Movie (1977),"most readily identified by the mighty "Airplane! (1980)," and most recently carried forth by raunchy music industry satire "Stadium Anthems (2018)."Gags in "The Naked Gun" rain down at a torrid pace; some deceptively high-brown, but most gloriously inane. It takes absolute geniuses to create such highly elevated stupidity.Is "The Naked Gun" somehow even better than its "Airplane!" forefather? By a nose, the vote here is "yes." While "Airplane!" also features Nielsen as a doctor (arguably even more straight-faced than Frank Drebin), that film's central character was the adequate Robert Hays, whereas "The Naked Gun" gives us Nielsen as the prime purveyor of every last morsel of hilarity. This is simply one of the greatest and most influential comedy films ever made. - (Was this review of any use to you? If so, let me know by clicking "Helpful." Cheers!)

Pretty much in the first few minutes, you can get a taste of how's the movie going to be and it's absolutely a historical and masterpiece. It's making fun of everyone involved in every possible and overtime it gets more and more redicilous in a good way because you can never predict how just a simple conversation will play out and usually it plays out absurd but everyone is acting like it's normal and it just works.It's a classic comedy from the 1980s with the geniune 80s feel and look with it's soundtrack, effets, people and just everything. It's a time capsule of everything great from that decade put together in one comedic movie.Leslie is just brillant and watching this movie now as an adult it brings back memories from childhood and I love it. You can also see O.J. Simpson acting few years before his incident.If you love classic comedy this is one of the must watch movies it's
1h 25 minutes of pure genius who is throwing everything he got at you and you will absolutly love it.
Comedy that parodies all cop movies clichés you could possibly think of and then some more already promises good entertainment. And when you add Leslie Nielsen in equation...7,5/10

"The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad" has so many laugh-out-loud moments it's impossible to list them all. There are even more smiles. The cast is terrific. They all do a great job. They play the material perfectly. "Naked Gun" has very little, if any, downtime. The short running time (85 min) is perfect. I remember seeing this movie in the theater (Movieworld, Douglaston, NY). I liked it a lot back then and I still like it a lot now. "Naked Gun" is great fun.

reviews.review_title: An Absolute Success from the ZAZ comedy team.
reviews.content: The writing team of David Zucker, Jim Abrahams and Jerry Zucker became a famous success after "Airplane!" made nearly 24 times its budget. Although "Kentucky Fried Movie" exceeded its own 33 times, it was their second film that gripped the attention of the critics and the public alike. They parlayed its success into the six episode show "Police Squad." After "Top Secret!," they went back to their short-lived television show and made the first of three "Naked Gun" films. Bringing back the show's star Leslie Nielsen and their signature machine gun paced humor, they crafted their finest work.Why did I spend 100 words, giving the background to this movie? The answer is that there is not much else to say without spoiling the hilarious content. I grew up on Abbott and Costello, Laurel and Hardy, and the Three Stooges; the first two are legendary and the third has a fiercely loyal following to this day. It has been difficult ever since for a comedy to impress me. There are only two comedies I have given a vote of ten stars. "The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!" is even better than "Spaceballs."Inept Lt. Frank Drebin (Leslie Nielsen) of Police Squad returns from abroad to the news that his partner (O.J. Simpson, when he was still funny) has been shot. We see it happen in the first of many sequences where we think the joke is over and then see it go on and on using wildly out-of-place props. Meanwhile, Vincent Ludwig (Ricardo Montalban), one of the most respected citizens in Los Angeles, has concocted an elaborate scheme to assassinate the visiting Queen of England! Thankfully, Lt. Drebin's boss (Oscar winner George Kennedy) and the rest of Police Squad have been assigned to protect her. That means Drebin must cross horns with Ludwig to prevent international disaster from culminatingat a Major League Baseball game! I am a *huge* baseball fan, and the climax is the most sensationally funny scene I have ever watched. I even saw my hometown team, although Zucker, Abrahams and Zucker clearly had no idea how bad the Seattle Mariners were at the time. They do prove that you don't have to know baseball to make it into the Television Booth.From an acting standpoint, "The Naked Gun" is about as good as it gets. Comedy is an entirely different discipline than dramatic acting. That is why you hear about certain actors simply as "comedians." Some critics and acting teachers believe comedy is harder. Nielsen is the king of treating outrageous scripts like they are "The Ten Commandments." He has been in many bad comedies, but with the right script, few are better at making even the best jokes funnier than they already are.Also notable is Ricardo Montalban. He publicly mentioned that he took the part for money to buy a new Chrysler. I immediately thought of Sean Connery upon reading this. After "Thunderball," Connery grew uninterested in playing James Bond, possibly from the strain of four films in four years plus the deplorable Japanese media's behavior during the shooting of "You Only Live Twice." In both that film and the later "Diamonds Are Forever," a role he only took for the cash, his boredom is unmasked in the two worst lead performances of the series.Such is not the case with Montalban. His facial expressions during the seventh inning stretch of the baseball game and his conversation with a terrorist whose name I would never wish on anybody look like they come from a man enjoying the part. The ability to keep external factors off the screen or stage is one of the fundamental cores of acting that has been lost on many talented thespians through the years. Montalban is not one of them. Other actors should take notice.

The second DVD up for viewing from our weekly grab was "The Naked Gun". I hadn't seen for a long time and figured I'd probably get more jokes in it than I did when I was 12.The story, if you haven't seen it for some reason, revolves around Frank Drebin (Nielsen), a wacky cop who is given the responsibility of overseeing the security for the impending visit of the Queen. Also on his plate is discovering what happened to his closest friend Nordberg(O.J Simpson, before he did you know what), who was shot at repeatedly on a drugs investigation. Drebin soon discovers there's a link between the visit and the attempt on Nordberg's life and sets about catching a would be assassin before they get to the Queen.From the same writers of the original "Flying High", there is some comedy gold in here. While some of it has aged, there's plenty of good stuff in there still. Besides discovering some innuendo I was oblivious to as a pre-teen, I found a few new jokes plus spotted the guy who played Elaine's dad in "Seinfeld" as a the Angels manager.One of the great comedies of the 80's.

reviews.review_title: SUCH A CLASSIC AND GREAT FILM!!!
reviews.content: The Naked Gun is such a wonderful franchise to start watching. It's hysterical throughout the film. Love story blossoming, silly antics that happen throughout the movie as well. I WOULD HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS MOVIE TO ANYONE ABOVE THE AGE 18!!!! A+++ Film

Laugh-A-Thon that was a Big HIt and spawned two Sequels, from the Creators of the similar Airplane (1980), this was a Spin off from the also Excellent TV Show. The Humor is mostly Slapstick, Puns, and Ridiculous situations rendered in Deadpan from Leslie Nielsen and the rest of Cast along for the Ride.Most of the Jokes Hit and it is a Delight to just let the thing play out in its own World where things are Crazy and get even Crazier as it goes along. Does tend to run out of steam at the Ballpark where Lt. Drubin runs amok and the One Setting leaves no room for things to broaden out even more.But it is a Scream most of the time. Someone said that Life is easy, Comedy is hard. But in this Nifty and Nutty Picture everything looks effortless. A Winner.

This is one of my favorite comedies of all time as well as parodies in the Parody subgenre of comedy. It's also another one of the best TV to movie adaptations as this film is a continuation of the show "Police Squad" which was a hit at the time but unfortunately had a short life span almost about the same as the TV show "Firefly". I honestly feel this is something most TV show should do when they don't get to go the distance, jump on another track to get there which this film did.The film is sort of an adolescent gem of mine as in my adolescence I began to explore more of the parody genre. And as a kid I have seen the TV show "Police Squad" which was one of my favorite comedy shows.When I saw they made a silver screen film based on that show it really blew me away, though once I rented out and saw the film I was just blown away. It was a real gut buster, I just laugh so hard watching this film that it almost hurts, that's something I rarely do for most comedy films, let alone not that many that can do that with me but thankfully this film is one of them and still is.This film is really a smoothie drink of parody as it parodies on the detective/cop shows of yesteryear, noir but also the James Bond franchise. I know that last one seems like a stretch but not as the film has some of the elements and format you would see on a Bond movie, from the very beginning, a scene with Frank goes to the crime lab and is introduced to gadgets, as well as the whole assassination plot, you name it for any Bond fan it's all there.The film is fully loaded with visual and verbal humor and hits the target on both counts. There is just so much that even on rewatch I can always find some more that might have flew by me making the film funnier than before. The dialog in the film is just hilarious, the characters have some colorful even deliciously bad lines but also some clever lines that can really catch you off guard, but what makes the dialog funny is the fact that everyone is just downright serious as if what their saying and what is going on is more or less the everyday norm.There are so many memorable scenes of hilarity, I'll just say a few of my favorites as talking about them can't do the comedy justice and I don't want to give too much away.The beginning which is to me one of the best openings in movies in general, it's always a great way to start off a film with a bang. It's a bit similar to the beginning of a Bond movie where we see a meeting held by an organization of evil much like Spectre from James Bond with some of the scummiest people in history all in one table and all up to no good as usual. This is obviously a set up for the plot of the film. But of course, in the end it results in one of my favorite battles of all time as well as the most hilarious as Frank just beats the crap out of everyone in the room, which is something most of us think of doing to scumbags all in the same room.There is a chase scene which is just hilarious and slightly thrilling with Frank being in the one car in the chase which is the last one you'd want to be in which is a Driving School car which let's just say gave the trainee driver one hell of a crash course. But what really made it even more hilarious was a death scene that could make Michael Bay envious.The final half with the Baseball game is just absolutely hilarious as not just is Frank trying to stop an assassination but also, he's lets just say making Baseball history.I really like the music which is sort of an old jazzy score which fits the film giving it an old-fashioned noir vibe to it. I really love the theme song which is one of my favorite themes of all time, just really gives you that empowering theme that the good guys are on the way to help. But also, it's one of my favorite intros as we see only the top perspective on an old squad car with the siren going and that car just seems to have a mind of it's own as it is just driving in some of the most random places let alone fit somehow, one place I like is where it parks at a doughnut shop with a dozen priced 1.99; yeah that would be a dream come true.The supporting characters and cast are solid from George Kennedy as Ed the chief who is really a solid straight man that just really helps in setting Frank straight though in the world of parody even he himself has his quarks. Ricardo Montalban whom is an honorable mention in favorite actors of mine, he's just great in the villain role as usual because it's Ricardo after all where he is suave and charismatic but also has that quiet sinisterness that simmers before it boils to the surface.But of course, what makes the film is Leslie Nelson himself one of my favorite comedic actors; this guy is practically the king of parody comedy as there's never been another since. Really love his performance because he just plays it straight from beginning to end which makes him and the film all the funnier. I really love the Frank Drebin character who is another of my honorable mention in fictional heroes.Frank is pretty much an old-fashioned cop from yesteryear but transported to our modern decade. This guy is so serious and tough that it's strange. He's really not that good at his job as he can be clumsy sometimes, a little rock headed both things inadvertently in his defense. Not quite with the times as he has sort of that attitude of a person from a different time. All these things would make him inefficient but despite the inefficiency he's does get the job done all the same if not smoothly.What make him endearing is that he how determined he is in completing his mission and just his overall never-ending crusade in fighting crime. Despite how tough things get for him (some of that inadvertently caused by himself) he keeps with it all the same. He's always does what's right no matter what and however he can because there really is no other way or any time to find a better way because it doesn't always exist, he just simply acts which makes him all the more effective in saving the day. I like also that he's a person that has some little quirks and a warmth to him, which makes him a guy you would like to be friends with though you probably want to keep your valuables away from him.This is a comedy classic that's full loaded with hilarity.Rating: 4 stars.

reviews.review_title: What a Parody Is Meant to Be.
reviews.content: Very good comedy that stars Leslie Nielsen in a Pink-Pantheresque role as a hapless detective who trips into every situation. Nielsen proves to be the ultimate straight-man in this laugh-a-minute-romp. Priscilla Presley, Ricardo Montalban, George Kennedy and yes O.J. Simpson are just super as the LAPD tries to stop an assassination plot on the Queen of England. Brain-washing and a whacked professional baseball game at the finale are two of the films major calling cards. Look for former baseball star Reggie Jackson and "Weird Al" Yankovic in hilarious cameo appearances. 4 stars out of 5.

Yes this is the one that kicked off that trio of infectious comedy slapstick. I actually like The Naked Gun's better than the Flying High's, only this time the brilliant Nielsen is at the helm, where he belongs. Lets face it, any film, that starts in Beirut is interesting. The great criminal here is Fantasy Island's Montalban, who has diabolic plans, ones that include brainwashing, which will aid him in assassinating the queen, where the queen really looks like the queen in this one. His captain is played by George Kennedy and like Nielsen, with being all so serious, he's created a likable character, where O.J. Simpson (yes, that's the one) plays his partner, to adequate ability (his only acting nomination is a bad one) more of a player than actor, you could say. Like the Flying High's the laughs keep coming, but here, it's at a more accelerated rate. Montage's have never been funnier, than the one you'll see here, especially, if you take pokes at Stone's Platoon, though that's kind of in bad taste. Taking pokes at Rambo would of been funnier. And this is the one, where Nielsen his eyes on the luscious Presley (God, if Elvis could see her now). She's sexy and really impresses with her character, Simpson an almost useless asset in these ones. Of course, there are those stupid moments, but that's expected in in slapstick. The brainwashing bits here, were the ones that didn't wash off. This really came at a time, we needn't something like this. It's slapstick, but it's original, smart, and fresh and garners laughs at a rate, that may'be even too quick. Excellent 89' slapstick comedy, never forgotten, and never watched once. Spawned two equally funny sequels.

Highly appealing pseudo-spin-off from Airplane! With much the same sense of humor only with a change of genre.Despite its cop protagonist, the tone of sustained witty silliness is a breath of fresh air.There's not really a lot more to say except it is at once ahead of its time and yet strangely enough without an imitator.

reviews.review_title: Best Comedic Performance in Film History.
reviews.content: Police spoofs begin and end with Naked Gun. So too does the art of deadpan. Lesley Nielsen's performance will never be bettered for as long as humans try to make each other laugh.In short, I love it.Thank you for the memories, Lesley.

reviews.review_title: an enjoyable exercise of outrageously silly gags
reviews.content: Clever, broadly funny comic spoof. The story begins as a Los Angeles police officer is nearly killed while investigating malfeasance on the local docks. He survives, and leaves clues for best friend Lieutenant Frank Drebin, a brainless fellow officer determined to try and apprehend the culprit. Drebin's investigation leads him onto the trail of Vincent Ludwig (Montalban), a well-respected businessman who may be involved in a plot to assassinate the Queen of England. Intentionally silly, often hilarious comedy has a few lulls as it nears the finale, but up until then it's an amusing barrage of ingenious gags, funny lines, and a steadily playful feel throughout. Nielsen is perfectly cast as the bumbling, obtuse officer, aided by a script that's both smart and consistently funny. ***

reviews.review_title: It was easy my dear. You forget I spent two years as a building contractor.
reviews.content: Frank Drebin is a cop on the trail of the world's worst terrorists and after a major successful operation returns to the United States, only to be upstaged by Weird Al Yankovic! This is the madcap world that Frank Drebin inhabits, a world where scientists find the ultimate deterrent for Graffiti artists, where a cop can fall into a birthday cake and a mantrap and both can be as bad as the other and a place where you take a risk when you cross a street or stick your face in a fan.However, when it comes to danger it's nothing compared to the attempted assassination of Queen Elizabeth during her forthcoming state visit. As Drebin's investigations continue he begins to suspect that respected industrialist Vincent Ludwig is connected to the plot and, against his superior's wishes he undertakes a lone crusade in order to prove his point.This is the best of the naked gun films and Leslie Neilsen's delivery is free from the over the top looks that so mark out his later turns in the role of Drebin, and the script unlike, the second film contains fewer references from the Police Squad series, with many good gags and memorable moments. As such this makes for an entertaining slice of hokum that leaves one with a smile of your face when you stop watching it.While it's not as good as the immense "Airplane" it is still worthy of a watch and very entertaining.

Leslie Nielsen heads a talented cast in the first "Naked Gun" film. He stars as Lt. Frank Drebin, and his bumbling pursuit of a criminal mastermind serves as the main plot in "The Naked Gun". Along the way he must also act as security for the Queen of England who is making a visit, which allows for more hilarious antics from one of the most funny actors in Hollywood.Nielsen is supported by a great cast including Priscilla Presley as his love interest Jane Spencer (the scene where they have "safe sex" is perhaps one of the funniest scenes I have ever seen in a movie), Ricardo Montalban as the villainous Vincent Ludwig, George Kennedy as Drebin's kind-hearted superior Captain Ed Hocken, and Nancy Marchand who is terrific as the dismissive Mayor Barkley."The Naked Gun" is not just a straight-comedy, there are literally countless spoofs littered throughout the film, as well as plenty of remarks on society. Aside from the "safe sex" scene other highly amusing scenes include Drebin and a learner driver, O.J. Simpsons blundered attack on some crooks, and Drebin destroying a valuable collection of artwork and statues.The main problem with the film though is that it seems to have aged. Several of the social context related jokes and themes seem lost in today's society, but were no doubt effective in their time. Being only 4 years old when the film was originally released it is a bit hard to remember though. Overall, an entertaining and enjoyable film.

reviews.review_title: Not as hilarious as back-in-the-day, but still pretty darn funny
reviews.content: Gut bustingly hilarious when it first came out, but now not quite as much. Leslie Nielsen is undeniably funny as police detective Frank Drebin, the incompetent but deadly serious hero of the film who must stop an assassination attempt on Queen Elizabeth, though the film's humor is really around the incidental moments occurring around the main story. Some of those moments still hold up and others do not. What was most surprising watching this film now is how leisurely paced it seems compared to contemporary rapid fire comedies. It was also very odd to see O.J. Simpson playing kind mild mannered police detective Nordberg. Overall, this is still a worthy comedy and certainly worth checking out.
If you grew up during the 80s & 90s like myself,, you couldn't avoid seeing this on cable. Lol!! Join Leslie Neilson as he clumsily hunts down crooks in this goofy comedy.

reviews.review_title: The Naked Gun: from the Files of Police Squad! - a good comedy-parody
reviews.content: The Naked Gun: from the Files of Police Squad! - a good comedy-parody with Leslie Nielsen in the title role. It is impossible to soberly evaluate the films of the Zucker brothers, but they can ridicule. And this film does a great job.

reviews.review_title: The First of The Funny Guns
reviews.content: 'The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!' is the first of Leslie Nielsen's hilarious Naked Gun trilogy, one that has stood the test of time and still makes me laugh out loud even after repeated viewings. The writing packs a solid story full of humour between words. The humour is an amusing ingredient of dry, slapstick, situational, spoofy and even a pinch of the political. The aim of the film was obviously to draw laughter and all three Naked Guns achieve that with ease. Nielsen does a superb job. It's nothing new that he's a master in his craft when it comes to comedy and he's at his best here. Priscilla does a good enough job of matching wits. George Kennedy is equally likable as the sidekick. It's time to revisit the sequels just to re-enjoy more of this adventure.

reviews.review_title: Stupid Comedy as an Art Form: One of the funniest films ever made
reviews.content: THE NAKED GUN: FROM THE FILES OF POLICE SQUAD! (1988) **** Leslie Nielsen, Priscilla Presley, Ricardo Montalban, George Kennedy, OJ Simpson.  Classic ZAZ comedy adaptation of the cult tv parody "Police Squad!" with Nielsen born to play dumb as a fox  Lt. Frank Drebin, the constantly bungling American cousin to French Inspector Clouseau, out to prevent an assassination attempt on the visiting Queen of England.  Classic slapstick and sight-gags aplenty

reviews.review_title: Non-stop laughs as Lt Frank Drebin tries to stop an assassin
reviews.content: Lt Frank Drebin of 'Police Squad' is back. After dealing with a group of well known 'Enemies of America' he returns to Los Angeles and is given the job of organising the security during a visit from Queen Elizabeth II. He is also investigating the shooting of his colleague Detective Nordberg; this leads him to businessman Vincent Ludwig, who is coincidentally involved in the organisation of the Queen's visit. It isn't long before Frank learns that Ludwig is involved in a plot to assassinate the Queen but unfortunately burns the evidence.Anybody hoping for a gritty drama will be sorely disappointed; this film features a series of gags that don't stop from start to finish. In fact the jokes come so thick and fast that if one gag doesn't work the next one will follow seconds later. The jokes are delightfully silly. Leslie Nielsen does a great job as Lt. Drebin; managing to keep a straight face in a variety of ridiculous situations. Ricardo Montalban impresses as the villain Ludwig and Priscilla Presley puts in a fun performance as love interest Jane. It is hard to pick out highlights as it is all pretty funny; I did particularly enjoy OJ Simpson's early scene where Nordberg confronts Ludwig's men, the scene where Frank ends up on top of the Queen and the final baseball game. Overall I'd definitely recommend this classic comedy to anybody who enjoyed the TV series or enjoys silly laughs.

Incompetent cop Frank Drebin (Leslie Nielsen) has to foil an attempt to assassinate Queen Elizabeth II.Leslie Nielsen really made a name for himself with goofy comedies. The best, of course, was "Airplane!". But the "Naked Gun" series was nothing to sneeze at. While I would not personally say the first is the best in the series, if it had not been successful we would never have seen parts two or three or possibly even other Nielsen movies. So, thank you.There is bathroom humor, sexual innuendo, and other crude elements. But there is also a fair amount of clever wordplay, and we see this is a smarter comedy than the more modern gross-out films (such as "American Pie"). This is the sort of comedy we should be emulating.

The great masters of comedy gave us, for my taste, the definitive film within the parody genre of police cinema. Frank Drebin, masterfully played by Leslie Nielsen, is a policeman in charge of the security of the Queen's visit to the United States. The presentation of the character, that of his associates and also that of the villain is a delight since the hectic pace of comedy together with the permanent search for gags at all levels does not give respite in the search for the ultimate goal: hilarity. It is a perfect movie to which all parodies should be compared. The film made school and is second to none.

Based on the short-lived TV series Police Squad, and from the geniuses that created Airplane! comes this brilliant spy spoof comedy that made an even bigger star of the once serious character actor. Basically Lieutenant Frank Drebin (Leslie Nielsen) is the clumsy and not all intelligent police detective working in the division of Los Angeles Police Department. When his colleague and best friend Nordberg (O.J. Simpson) is shot and recovering in hospital, the underground investigation leads him to suspect businessman Vincent Ludwig (Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan's Ricardo Montalban) is up to something. He is planning to brainwash someone to assassinate Queen Elizabeth II (Jeannette Charles) visiting the United States, and he gets his personal assistant Jane Spencer (Priscilla Presley) to distract him from the case. Eventually, after many stupid mishaps and embarrassing accidents, Frank comes to the conclusion that the assassination attempt will take place at a major league baseball game the Queen will be attending. In the end, Frank stops the brainwashed player, Ludwig gets what he deserves, and Jane admits that she loves him for real, all just in time for Nordberg arriving fully recovered. Also starring George Kennedy as Ed Hocken, Nancy Marchand as Mayor, Raye Birk as Pahpshmir, Susan Beaubian as Mrs. Nordberg, Ed Williams as Ted Olsen, 'Weird Al' Yankovic as 'Weird Al' and Lawrence Tierney as Angels Manager. Nielsen is fantastic as the bumbling spy who says and does the stupidest things, but you can't help but love him, from the opening police siren with catchy theme music and onwards, the scripting is witty, and the slapstick, sight and gross out gags are hilarious, it certainly deserves it place in the book 1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die, a superb comedy. Detective Frank Drebin was number 47 on The World's Greatest Comedy Characters, and the film was number 14 on The 50 Greatest Comedy Films. Outstanding!

The stage curtains open ...When I saw this on the silver screen in late 1988, I had never heard of Police Squad, and in fact, I had never even knew about this movie. The girl I was dating at the time chose it, and so we went. I never laughed so hard. The poster alone will let you know exactly what you are in for, and this first movie of the Naked Gun Series doesn't disappoint.Frank Drebin (Leslie Nielsen) of Police Squad as been called in to investigate an attempt on his partner's life, and what he stumbles into is a conspiracy to assassinate Queen Elizabeth, who is touring America. Frank teams up with the secretary of his chief suspect, and what follows is a series of hijinks and mishaps that had most of us rolling in the aisles with laughter. Frank gets into hot water with the mayor, so he must beat the clock to foil the assassination attempt, win the girl, and secure his place back on the police force.I think part of what made this movie such a hit with me was that I went in blind, not really knowing what I was in for. There was no built up anticipation or hopes, just a young couple going to watch a funny movie. It is your classic inept detective comedy in the vein of other classics such as the Pink Panther and the Police Academy movies, and others that would follow like "Who's Harry Crumb?" and "The Other Guys". The blue print works as long as the movie and the acting is done well, and "The Naked Gun" certainly did that.I highly recommend this film to any comedy enthusiast. If you haven't seen this one yet, I know you would enjoy it. The cast does feature O.J. Simpson before his trial, but if that doesn't bother you, then you should give it a go. This is a classic now, and all these years later, I will still watch it from time to time and laugh just as much as the first time I saw it. 8 stars out of 10.

reviews.review_title: "Nice Beaver". "Thanks I recently had it stuffed."
reviews.content: After learning that his colleague officer Nordberg has been shot multiple times and placed in intensive care Detective Frank Drebin sets to work in finding out who was responsible for this shooting. Worse is to follow though when Drebin discovers that the man responsible for the shooting is also planning on assassinating Queen Elizabeth 2 and sets to work foiling the mad man's plans in his own unique way...Sometimes even when films are made a long time ago they can still produce the laughs and the original Naked Gun film is one such example; it arguably uses the easiest approach to gain laughs (slapsticks and pratfalls) much like we used to see in the Pink Panther films, but it is mostly used to very good effect here and I have to admit that even after all these years I still found the film very very funny.One thing that I think has always made this film work so well is Leslie Nielsen; his dead-pan comic style and complete lack of awareness of all of the chaos that he is causing along the way is actually one of the things that makes what you see so funny. There's a sort of endearing innocence to Drebin (whereby the good intention is always there, but his approach leaves a lot to be desired).The plot is vague and only basically outlined, but in all honesty who really watches spoof or parody films for the plots. If you're just looking for laughs then this film has them in abundance - I don't want to spoil it for those who haven't seen the film, but trust me there are plenty on offer.This is Leslie Nielsen's film all the way and he really steals the show here; the likes of George Kennedy, Priscilla Presley & Ricardo Montalban are good in support, but they don't hold a candle to Nielsen. OJ Simpson didn't have much screen time in this one which wasn't much of an issue for me as I always felt that acting was never really his forte.In these grim times - particularly in the UK where we're still in our 3rd COVID-19 lockdown :-( The Naked Gun is a nice piece of escapist fun that is still capable of bringing the laughs after all these years.

reviews.review_title: Hilarious film that's more clever than some people realize
reviews.content: It's difficult to review a comedy, which is why I haven't attempted it until now. (What do you say, after all? "This is a really, really funny movie!") The great thing about "The Naked Gun" is that, in addition to being genuinely funny, it's a smart little film. Perfect example: Raymond Chandler fans will get a kick out of the reference to "Farewell, My Lovely". Upon his first meeting with Priscilla Presley's character, Leslie Nielsen (as Lt. Frank Drebin) notes in the voice-over, "She was giving me a look I could feel in my hip pocket." This line is lifted directly from Chandler's novel, but it's so subtle and fits into the film so well that viewers who know nothing of Chandler won't feel left out. This, along with Nielsen's lovably goofy performance, is what separates the work of the Zucker brothers from knockoffs like "Loaded Weapon". Sure, you've seen "The Naked Gun" already...but see it again and you'll pick up on things you didn't notice the first time. (Single best moment of the film: O.J. Simpson's absurdly prolonged reaction to being shot by Ricardo Montalban's goons. It sends me into fits of laughter every time!)

reviews.review_title: A parody movie that serves it's purpose
reviews.content: Due to Leslie Nielson's tragic and untimely death, I decided to visit one of his many films I haven't had the pleasure of seeing. I saw Airplane many years ago, I saw Scary Movie 3 and 4 in the theaters, and saw Creepshow last fall. I didn't however see Nielsen's parody films which made him famous like The Naked Gun trilogy and Spy Hard. So I finally put one on to watch what I had missed...22 years later.It's true you don't know what you have until it's gone, and you appreciate it/them more when they're gone. I knew who Corey Haim was before he died and saw License to Drive a couple months before his death, but became somewhat obsessed with him when he died. Same thing applies with Michael Jackson, Greg Giraldo, and a number of others. Leslie Nielsen may be a victim to my awkward obsession. After watching this gem, he very well could be. If that's a good thing.Leslie plays Frank Drebbin a policy officer who likes to think he is doing a good job, when really, he doesn't know what he is doing, and when he tries to do something good, he gets himself and others hurt. Drebbin now has to protect Queen Elizabeth II from being assassinated at a California Angels baseball game during the seventh inning stretch. Although the plot sounds very serious, it delivers an uncountable number of laughs in the process.Going into this, aware of it being a parody/spoof film, I was nothing but skeptical. A parody film? Hasn't that genre been beaten, trashed, abused, and spat on by the duo of Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer? But in the eighties and nineties, David Zucker knew how to be funny and original simultaneously. Rather than cramming over thirty pop culture characters/references that, most of the time, lack a purpose or dimension, Zucker took in a cop that wanted to do the right thing but unknowingly made matters either unclear or even worse than they already were.The goal for a parody film is to make it play like a regular film. It's supposed to feel like an actual film, but it should poke fun at all of the movie clichés (i.e. comforting wife when husband was in ER). One cop would never bring up the worst possible outcomes that could happen to the wife when her husband is in the hospital bed near death. So in a nutshell, when constructing a parody film, don't focus on setting a record for the most pop culture characters utilized in an eighty minute film. Make it like a real film and just poke fun at common clichés.The Naked Gun is definitely a winner, and probably takes the cake for my favorite parody film. Leslie Nielsen's acting was memorable as well my first time seeing O.J. Simpson acting in anything. I never thought I'd say or type this but, we have a great parody film on our hands.Starring: Leslie Nielsen, Priscilla Presley, Ricardo Montalbán, George Kennedy, O. J. Simpson, and Nancy Marchand. Directed by: David Zucker.
Crazy literal humour from Leslie neilson and cast, always a fun watch with quotable lines!

Just a bunch of goofball humor, Leslie Nelson is hilarious as the aloof detective "SSStriiikee". You can't help but laugh at the absolute ridiculousness. Priscilla Presley really shines in this movie. Good ole fashion funny.

reviews.review_title: Surely, You Can Never Be Serious
reviews.content: A must-see for any Airplane!-enthusiast, The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad! is so close to perfect, from beginning to end, you'll wonder why the defunct TV program didn't last. For, it's all the same jokes.Perhaps that was their gamble: only the 50 or less people who saw the show – me, included – would recognize these replayed jokes. Nevertheless, this movie is downright hilarious and it never, ever lets up or changes course.Very few creators (Abrahams, Zucker & Zucker) of comedy can achieve such heights. Despite some recent setbacks, they've been behind masters of slapstick – Airplane!, Top Secret! and this one from Police Squad! – wow, they definitely like to shout a lot. So, if you're into silly humor, like I happen to be, watch this. Of course, if you haven't already, shame on you. Check this Beaver out now.Police Squad's Frank Drebin (Nielsen) beats up innocents and terrorist alike, whether by stumbling into them or hitting them with his runaway car. But now, he MUST SAVE THE QUEEN, who happens to be visiting their town of L.A.Evil, eeeevil Vincent Ludwig (Montalban) has plans for the perfect assassin and his lovely, but blameless assistant Jane (Presley) serves her purpose of spying on Drebin. You know how the story goesFrank: It's the same old story. Boy finds girl, boy loses girl, girl finds boy, boy forgets girl, boy remembers girl, girl dies in a tragic blimp accident over the Orange Bowl on New Year's Day. Jane: Goodyear? Frank: No, the worst.This review would be increased tenfold if I was to lay out (okay, fine, copy) all the fantastic quotes, but this is a great example of what you're getting yourself into. If you like the above, you'll love the rest of the movie.And if you have seen this movie, and it's been awhile, like for me, watch it again. I practically had it memorized from seeing it probably two dozen times as a kid, and still, I was cracking up and enjoyed every last scene. Yeah, even with OJ Simpson as one of the leads.Side Note: As much as I love pure slapstick – not the crappy Vampires Suck and Disaster Movies of today - my only (SLIGHT) complaint is when they look at the camera to indicate even they think this is crazy. They do it a little too much in this movie – but not enough to downgrade the movie. Yes, my favorite comedy of all time, Airplane!, barely did it once or twice – but for 99% of that movie, it was a perfectly insane world.

Hilarious slapstick-comedy. Clever, witty dialogue and brilliant sight- gags. So quotable. The problem with these types of movies is that once the initial novelty wears off, the movie runs out of ideas, leaving the last half of the movie quite lame. Naked Gun doesn't have this problem. It stays original, unpredictable and funny right until the end. It also knows when to end.Great performance by Leslie Nielsen in the lead role. Can't think of too many other comedians or actors who could have pulled off the role. George Kennedy is solid as the straight man to Nielsen's clown.Probably the movie that started the run of spoof genre movies of the late-80s/early-90s. Unfortunately the genre has now become rather low- brow, unoriginal and far too prevalent.

From the goofs that created Airplane! and Rat Race (David Zucker, Jim Abrahams, Jerry Zucker), here comes The Naked Gun, based on their short-lived TV series (Police Squad!).Leslie Nielsen is dunderheaded Lieutenant Frank Drebin, who is part of L.A.'s Police Squad. He's been their for awhile, but isn't the sanest person in the sanitarium. When the Police Squad is called on to protect the Queen of England on her visit to America, Frank is the main man. Along the way, he meets someone who may be in a plot to assassinate her.This may look like a plotless comedy, and it somewhat is. Just like Airplane!, it manages to have lots of sketches while still in the plot (unlike Austin Powers, for instance). Like the scene in Ludwig's office when Frank, let's say, changes it's decor. Nielsen is like his other films-the type of character who doesn't think he's funny but he is. Some jokes are tasteless (like the statues), but some are full of taste. Well, now that I think about it, there weren't many tastefull jokes, but The Naked Gun still made me laugh.There weren't as many funny parts as Airplane! (which was one huge laugh), but some scenes were side-splitting. The ending momentum slowed down some at the baseball game finale, and his checking the players got old after awhile. It was just in to stretch the running time to 85 minutes (which was a perfect length, by the way). Besides what I did, there's not much more to say about it except it's really funny and recommended.My rating: 8/10Rated PG-13 for sex-related humor.

Movies just don't get much funnier than "The Naked Gun." From the people that brought you "Airplane!" comes a comedy in a similar vein, stuffed with one-liners and sight gags. Leslie Nielsen is perfect for this kind of comedy. He's droll and oblivious to the absurdity around him. He takes everything completely seriously but manages to make fun of himself in the process somehow anyway. It's hard to explain but you'll see what I mean when you watch the movie.Ever since "The Naked Gun" was released in 1988, it's been one of those movies I watch every once in a while when I just want some mindless entertainment or when there's nothing else on, and it never fails to disappoint. It holds up well (I think even better than "Airplane!") and deserves to be counted among the best screen comedies ever made.Grade: A+

What makes The Naked Gun so funny is it's small moments; things like when Leslie Nielson knocks a fisherman of the pier when parking his car, when he and Priscilla Presley come out of a movie laughing, only for the audience to see that the movie they just left was 'Platoon', the part at the baseball game where a fan shouts "It's Enrico Pallazzo!"; those are the really funny moments in The Naked Gun. That's not to say the bigger gags, such as the part where Detective Nordberg is shot or the thing with the fish don't work, but it's the film's attention to detail that is most definitely it's main asset.The Naked Gun opens with an utterly hilarious sequence which sees a police siren, obviously atop of a police car parade through all sorts of areas that it isn't supposed to, all done to a backdrop of very farcical music. From this point on, you know you're going to be in for a lot of silliness, and if it's silliness you want, The Naked Gun is definitely your film. The plot of the movie is largely irrelevant, and serves only as a means to spoof several clichés of the police thriller genre; which is all the plot should serve as in a gag based comedy such as this.Leslie Nielson is the perfect man for this sort of film, as he has proved over and over; even when he's stood doing nothing he looks silly; he has a look that is made for comedy, and this is his finest hour. This movie is also the finest hour for the ZAZ team; unlike with the messy and largely unfunny "Airplane!", they've managed to get almost everything spot on here. The jokes are funny; for every one that doesn't work, there's twenty that do, the lead man is on top form and the situation is silly enough to provide lots of room for gags, and that room is filled as far as is possible.If you're more a fan of intelligent comedy, then I recommend checking out The Naked Gun anyway because I very much doubt that anyone can sit through this movie without laughing. Forget "Airplane!", THIS is the finest ZAZ comedy.

reviews.review_title: "One Man's Trash is Another Man's Treasure!" Cancelled on TV, the "POLICE SQUAD!" Project taken to PARAMOUNT PICTURES and the "movies" , with great $ucce$$!!
reviews.content: The creative team of Zucker/Abrahams/Zucker were "overnight" successes with the public acceptance and Box Office $ucce$$ of their AIRPLANE!(Paramount, 1980). This opened the door to them for other projects. So, to the small screen of Television Land they did travel.Utilizing the same type of "tongue in cheek", verbal punning and sight gag loaded spoofing humor as AIRPLANE, they chose to launch a double barreled assault on the Cop Show. The result was POLICE SQUAD!(1982).The series produced a grand total of six(6) measly episodes, but what a six episodes they were. Each was a little gem on its own, and would have worked well as those "old time" 2 Reelers Comedies once so popular at the theatre, featuring the likes of Laurel & Hardy, The Three Stooges, Edgar Kennedy, 'Joe McDoakes', Pete Smith, etc.Well, some joker with a position as an Executive at the American Broadcasting Company (ABC) TV Network pronounced the series as a candidate for the 'old Axe' because ".....you have to pay too much attention to the episodes on your TV.", or some such dribble.So away went "POLICE SQUAD" with Captain/Lieutennant/Sergeant Frank Drebbin(Leslie Nielsen), ne'er to be heard from again. WRONG! In 1988, the concept with Leslie Nielsen starring rose again as THE NAKED GUN: From The Files of Police Squad!( Paramount, 1988). It was a feature film, one that required viewing at a movie house and paying an admission. Well, with 2 sequels following, it's kinda obvious that it was successful, where it counts, with the public!* The story opens up with a scene of a big meeting of America's Enemies. Among those being portrayed are Castro, Khadaffi, Arafatt, Idi Amin, the Ayatola Khomani and others. Their meeting being broken up by the sudden appearance of Frank Drebbin, on special Government assignment.Back home in L.A., he is met at the Airport by his boss, Captain Ed Hocken(George Kennedy)who informs him of the coming visit of State by Her Majesty, Queen Elizabeth II to Los Angeles. A visit complicated by the Underground Operations by Some Murderous Gang of Drug Smugglers. The city Fathers are concerned over some Murders connected to them. Also, Detective Nordberg (O.J. Simpson) lies close to death in Hospital after attempting to infiltrate the Mob.The plot takes us on a merry chase, all 'round L.A., before winding up at the California Angels' "Big A" Ball Park in Aneheim.Without getting into particulars, let's just say that this is the Crown Jewels of the whole picture. We are treated to a succession of super gags, each as good or better than the last. The back-drop of a Baseball Game between the Angels and the Seattle Mariners provides the opportunity for Leslie Nielasen to perform a true Tour-de-Force of Comedic Performance that will remain unmatched for many a year! (Oh, Hell! Just see it, next chance you get!)

Leslie Nelson is detective Frank Drebin in this quirky spoof of Police Squad. Drebin will always gets his man but he has quite a few comedic follies doing it. This movie is worth watching if you enjoyed Nelson in films like 'Airplane!' and 'Dracula: Dead And Loving It'.If you enjoyed The Naked Gun or other Nelson films then you might like other comedy movies with a similar theme (goofy police, spies, detectives type films): 'Fletch', 'Police Academy', 'Turner and Hooch', 'Dead Men Don't Wear Plaid' or 'Spies Like Us'.The Naked Gun is a spoof, and if another comedy spoof is what you want then try such films as 'Robin Hood: Men in Tights', 'Galaxy Quest', 'Spaceballs' or even 'Young Frankenstein'.8.5/10

reviews.review_title: Easily the best of the goofy trilogy
reviews.content: The three "Naked Gun" movies from 1988, 1991 and 1994 are all extremely goofy comedies starring Lesley Nielsen, Priscilla Presley, George Kennedy and OJ Simpson. They're consistently amusing and, pretty much, interchangeable. If you like one, you'll like 'em all. Priscilla was one of the most beautiful women to walk the planet in her prime and looks great in these films. The first two were hugely successful at the box office; the third one didn't do bad, but nowhere near as good. Whether or not you prefer one to another depends on the story and guest stars. In my opinion, this first one is easily the best simply because it's more consistently amusing and often laugh-out-loud funny, which explains my high grade.As for the two sequels go, I slightly prefer part 3, but all three come in handy when you want to turn off your brain and enjoy something silly.The film runs 85 minutes and was shot in the Los Angeles area and San Diego.GRADE: A-

reviews.review_title: Nielsen takes charge of another Zucker, Abrahams and Zucker gem
reviews.content: What started in 1977 with "Kentucky Fried Movie" continues again in "The Naked Gun," a film version of the TV series "Police Squad!" only this time detective/cop films are the culprit, seemingly perfect fodder for spoofing and the Zucker, Abrahams and Zucker one-two punch of subtle literalist humor and preposterous gags. The only real difference between this and 1980's "Airplane!" is that Lesley Nielsen takes command of this film as opposed to an all-cast effort.Nobody must be able to keep a straighter face than Nielsen. As Lt. Frank Drebin, the things he must do and say while remaining ignorant to their comedic value are absurd in quantity and quality. Drebin is when James Bond meets Inspector Clouseau -- he's completely oblivious yet he knows exactly what he's doing. As contradictory as that sounds, it's completely true. Nielsen does both incredible deadpan and slapstick, a highly specialized skill for a comedian, and unfortunately for the rest Nielsen's career, that's all he has. Nevertheless, it's perfect for "The Naked Gun."Unlike "Airplane!", this film has to be a bit more plot-focused because the cop/detective genre necessitates it. "Airplane!" could descend into utter chaos, whereas "The Naked Gun" feels obligated to make sense in some regard. All you need to know is that O.J Simpson's character got shot and the investigation leads to the uncovering of a possible assassination attempt on the life of Queen Elizabeth II. The challenge for the viewer is to forget making sense of what's going on and pay attention to the small details that make these films even funnier. In some scenes this is easier than others and for the most part, the easier it is, the better "The Naked Gun" gets.A lot of the times these are the laughs that make you smile inside instead of laughing out loud, but especially toward the end when the humor becomes more slapstick, "The Naked Gun" really takes off ... pardon the "Airplane!" lingo. Another fun film from these guys.

The Naked Gun came out before i was born, and when i first watched it was way too young to appreciate lots of its humour. Still, there was enough low-brow and physical comedy to crack me up, and it was one of my early favourite movies. While I've outgrown a lot of slapstick movies that I liked a good few years back, I can still watch The Naked Gun and laugh, and I even get the jokes that went way over my head as a kid.The film is somewhat a movie remake of its predecessor "Police Squad!", it couldn't be simpler, and that's the way they want it. Lt. Frank Drebin has to to clear the name of his partner Norberg (The killer OJ Simpson to be precise) while protecting the life of Queen Elisabeth, in Los Angeles on a tour of America. For ninety minutes, the movie exploits, and frequently ignores, the plot in the name of jokes. Just plain and simple, this movie is out to make you laugh, and it will sink to any depth to get there.

reviews.review_title: Wildly inconsistent collection of gags, a handful of them hilarious.
reviews.content: Bad joke. Bad joke. Worse joke. Bad joke. Good joke. Great joke. Great joke. Bad joke. Worse joke. And repeat. That's the template for this admirably relentless collection of spoof gags and non-sequiturs (I know it says non-sequiturs on Wikipedia, but I thought of it first, honest I did), which rose from the ashes of cancelled TV show Police Squad. Leslie Nielsen is Frank Drebin, the incompetent cop trying to thwart the assassination of the Queen, who's on a state visit to L.A. Ricardo Montalbian - a leading man for Esther Williams in his early days - is the crimelord, while George Kennedy plays Nielsen's sidekick. We begin with a particularly unfunny fight scene, but the film soon gets into its stride via a hilarious credits sequence and O.J. Simpson's slapstick dunking, before reaching a peak around the midway point, with Nielsen's dressing down by the mayor, the dockyard shoot-out ("I can't hear you! Don't fire the gun while you're talking!") and the banquet stop-and-search. The film draws on slapstick, satire and spoofery to similarly variable ends, aided by a cast that's ever-game, if only as good as the material. As I've said before, spoofing is generally the preserve of the lazy, but at least Zucker and co are selective, and largely parody deserving targets.

reviews.review_title: The comedy team of Zucker, Abrahams and Zucker.
reviews.content: The Naked Gun: From the files of Police Squad! (1988) marks the return of Lt. Frank Drebin, a character he played on the short lived television series POLICE SQUAD! This time around, one of his colleagues Nordberg (O.J. Simpson) is hospitalized after a botched undercover operation. Lt. Frank Drebin and his partner (George Kennedy) have to pick up where Nordberg left off. This leads him to Vincent Ludwig (Ricardo Montelban). Whilst investigating him he comes across his personal assistant Jane (Priscella Pressley). Drebin's smitten by Jane. But as the movie progresses: Will Drebin find true love? Can he catch Ludwig in a criminal act? What will happen to Nordberg? Do I need to see this movie? All questions will be answered when you watch THE NAKED GUN: FROM THE FILES OF POLICE SQUAD!!!A funny movie that's followed by two less than spectacular sequels. This one is highly recommended!

reviews.review_title: The naked gun is all senses stupid, but it's absolutely halarious.
reviews.content: The naked gun never stops to be serious throughout the whole runing time. Usually that's a recipe for a unfunny mess of a film. In the case of this movie it is actually a recipe for success. The jokes in this movie are all halarious, and the slapstick is setup excellently. Also the characters are all stupid in kind of a smart way. Overall this movie is comedic genius and the best kind of slapstick. I recommend this movie very much, It's is a must watch.

Today watched The Naked Gun again after not having watched it in years. Leslie Nielsen is one of my favorite comedy actors. Two of my favorite movies are Airplane and Airplane Two. The Naked gun is funny but, its no airplane. Its the same type of humor though.I think the big laughs are towards the beginning of naked gun. Later in the movie the laughs are not as frequent.My favorite scene is the one where the air bag of frank Drebin's car deploys as he parks his car. He does not realize that his car keeps rolling directly behind. When the car passes him he pulls out his badge and orders the driver less car to stop. He does not realize that the car has no driver so when the car does not stop he shots it. And it catches on fire while still rolling. That scene made me laugh so hard. How can frank not even know its his car that is rolling my him. Wow.I felt better after having watched the Naked gun. And I am glad I watched it after all those years. And I was surprised at how funny it was. Now I will have to re-watch the sequel's The Naked Gun.

reviews.review_title: Adore Leslie Neilson..Laugh until I cry !
reviews.content: I can watch this movie over and over and STILL laugh out loud...classic comedy! The deadpan slapstick humor is fantastic in this and I have yet to tire of this movie!I don't think this will ever become extinct...right up there with Animal House, Airplane 48 Hours, Beverly Hills Cop and Fast Times At Ridgemont High. An absolute classic of its generation.
Excellent gags that i have yet seen any modern movie live up to. I was laughing out loud many times from start to end. I can't say the same for many other movies in this genre. A must watch.

In order to properly criticize David Zucker's "The Naked Gun" you must first understand that picking on the hastily written superficial plot would be missing the point. The plot can be whatever it wants to be. This movie is about sticking as many slapstick set-pieces as humanly possible in every single frame and every single moment. It's live-action Looney Tunes.But still, what is it about? Well, it's about the incompetent and delusional police Detective Frank Drebin (Leslie Nielsen) who must foil an attempt to assassinate Queen Elizabeth II. Take a time to absorb the last half of that sentence and get used to it. Sudden escalations are this movie's bread and butter. They also add up to making this one of the funniest movies ever made. And it should be, considering how much it defies any notion of continuity or just plain sense! The humor is everywhere--both up front and center represented by Debrin's cartoon-level ridiculous misadventures and in the background hidden as easy to miss Easter eggs. I am sure that on my only viewing of this I've missed some things.Timing is everything when it comes to comedy, but director David Zucker--who also contributed to the writing--takes his fellow writers Jim Abrams and Jerry Zucker and refurbish their "Police Squad" television series into sustained humor. Every bit of it is as ridiculous as it is funny. Take the scene in which Drebin forgets to apply the hand-brake to his car which then starts running off on its own and literally blows up. Such incompetence would have him kicked off from the force, but here, it's treated like it's not out of the ordinary and the show goes on. The pace is relentless, its supposedly serious noir, only being present because stuff happens to go on at night sometimes and its dialogue punchy, unforgiving with a generous quantity of dry but smart PG-13 humor.Yet with comedy putting itself on the pedestal of political responsibility, there is a genuine question of social innuendos and commentary. I am delighted to say there is none. While at first I found the way the movie it's bullying the Queen a supposed joke brought on by the opposing political views of the US and its UK buddy with which it has well-known history, the ending took place at a baseball game--a religion in the US, and it was as cruel to it as it was to the Queen itself. This is Zucker making it clear that the movie will harass anything for fun, including numerous terrorist leaders/organizations--pure comedy.

This is by far the best Leslie Nielson comedy. Almost every joke worked, and even the ones that didn't were done as well as they could be.Leuitenant Frank Drebin has to stop the murder of Queen Elizibeth, while trying to also figure out who's behind the attack of his police friend Norwood (OJ Simpson). Yes, the movie has no real plot and it's a bunch of gags thrown together, and yes, it begins to run out of steam by the end, but this is just a hilarious movie. Leslie Nielson's serious manner is perfect for his ridiculous lines, and the constant sight gags are hilarious. Even Pricilla Presley managed to be amusing.Great job to the Zuckers for their wonderful creation.My rating: *** 1/2 out of ****. 83 mins. PG-13 for sexual humor.
It's just amazing. I recommend it to anyone that likes these kinds of comedies.

reviews.review_title: No Hot Dogs Were Harmed During The Making Of This Film!
reviews.content: While we can all agree that the folks behind films like this and 'Airplane' are generally comedy geniuses and that Leslie Nielson delivers the parts superbly, I think it might also be fair to say that a lot of it hasn't aged that brilliantly. The humour isn't quite as sophisticated as we expect it to be these days, at least not quite as clever. It's silly and slapstick, which many people can't appreciate.At the time it did it's job and it did it well and I remember it being funnier then. Don't get me wrong it still gets a good few twitters of laughter from me and I still enjoyed it, because it's not an offensive film in general and neither is it filled with Sex, Drugs, Violence, Etc, but I do wonder how many more points it would have scored back when I first watched it.Frank Drebin is back on patrol following his escapades in 'Police Squad'. What ensues is a mixture of 'James Bond' and 'Murder She Wrote'. Chaos goes everywhere with Frank and it's usually very funny, but does he solve the case in time to save the innocent? You'll have to watch it.I seem to recall that the second film in the franchise was the best overall and will look out for that one too.

"The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad!" tells the story of a very motivated, yet very chaotic inspector at the police forces, who is hired to take care of the Queen's safety during her visit in the United States while having to battle a gangster boss whose aim it is to turn innocent people into cold-blooded killers.The movie is in many parts a great parody of the countless police action movies that have been around and inspired similar modern approaches such as "Austin Powers" or "Johnny English". I have to admit that, though I'm normally not a big fan of slapstick, many of the gags are presented very clever and show a very decent humor instead of just going for the easy laughs. Nontheless the plot remains nonsense of course and thus you shouldn't expect a great movie in terms of tension or story. On the other hand, those parts are clearly not in the focus of this title and so I think we can all live with this fact.All in all this is a great parody that still convinces with clever humor even decades after its production. It is, however, not a great film in itself and so I'll give it a medium rating but still advise to give it a try.

reviews.review_title: The movie that made me laugh so loud!!
reviews.content: The funniest scene is the baseball umpire sequence!!

reviews.review_title: It will have you in stitches
reviews.content: If you don't think that this movie is absolutely hilarious, then you don't know great comedy.Leslie Nielsen is one of the funniest actors of all time in my book. He is at his comedic best in this movie. His delivery of the most ridiculous lines with a completely straight face really sells the comedy.Leslie Nielsen plays Lt. Frank Drebin of Police Squad a special division of the police force. He bumbles his way through investigations in a manner somewhat reminiscent of Peter Sellers' Inspector Dreyfus.This movie is actually a continuation of the show Police Squad! They kept much of the same cast but made it a little more mainstream. Give this movie a watch and then if you liked that, find a copy of Police Squad! and watch that too.

This is the first and the best of THe Naked Gun movies. Leslie Nielsen is hysterical because he always looks like he's taking it so seriously. He and George Kennedy must have had a ball making this film. Its a joy from start to finish because if one gag doesn't make you laugh the next five will. They just come so fast you have to watch carefully to keep up with it. What gets me is that for the first thirty years of his career Leslie Nielsen was a dramatic actor. Airplane was probably the first comedy that he ever did and yet all people know him for is being a comedian. Watching this film now is uncomfortable for me in just one aspect, it has OJ Simpson in it. We all know he did it.

Man, Zucker really knows how to keep the laughs coming with his trademark brand of comedy that includes spoofing serious situations (whether or not they have appeared in actual movies) wordplay, sight gags and through the vehicle of Leslie Nielson- deadpan humor.No punches are pulled. If it will get a laugh, they use it. Not much for plot; it's mainly a bunch of hilarious situations cobbled together to form that ideal of entertainment portion sizes: the screen film.My favorite scene in this film was the mayor's announcement of the Queen's impending arrival and their security measures with Frank and the mike. Boy, did i have soda squirting out of my every orifice! Priscilla Presley is beautiful. I found it really heartwarming that she was a successful actress in her own right after being married to one of the most famous celebrities ever (Elvis).

reviews.review_title: One of the funniest movies ever made
reviews.content: Pure comedic genius. This movie was funnier than all the other Naked Gun movies combined.
"It's Enrico Pollazzo!!!"... The greatest comedic line in the history of cinema!!!

The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad! is classic slapstick comedy. It had a great story and right on dialogue that was perfectly said by the great actor Leslie Neilsen (who was the right pick for the role of Lt. Frank Drebin as well as the costars). Gags just keep happening at the right time, nicely paced throughout the film. The best scene in the film is when Frank Drebin accidentally tops a surprised Queen Elizabeth! And Ira Newborn's great score for this film and the successive two films is inventive, adding to the laugh out riot tone. A near perfect film that is a must see for anyone who is into comedy . . . a solid 9 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: The movie that is so funny you will see it once and forget it.
reviews.content: People always say this is a funny movie. But they do not see more then once and do not remember it. The trues is it is not funny. It is just very very stupid. Do not see it. It is overrated. And like most comedies it is badly written. I do not known why people like it. It is so stupid. It is not a 7.6. It is just pooh. I give 4 out of 10. Because it is pooh pooh. It not funny at all. It is just weird pooh pooh. I do not know how any one could laugh at it. It is just awful. It could never have been made. And do not know why people think it so funny. People who think this is funny will just laugh at any thing, This is just cheap laughs.

reviews.review_title: ... having your nuts bit of by a Laplander... That's the way I want it...
reviews.content: "Naked Gun" is one of the few screw ball comedies that crack me up every time. There's something in it, that just wont age willingly, it stays fresh. Or maybe it's just my sense of humor, or the the fabulous acting of Leslie Nielsen, I laugh every time when I watch it.Leslie Nielsen plays Drebin, a detective, who spills out hard boiled inner dialogue and keeps his stone cut expression no matter what. He fights crime to the last. And with Drebin the crime wont last: it churns up into a chaos. Priscilla Presly is Jane Specner, a secretary of Vincent Ludwig (Ricardo Montalban) the bad guy of the film. Jane also is the la fem fetal whom Drebin falls head over heels. There is a plot about assassination of Queen Elizabeht II, but as this type of comedy works, the over all plot is pretty meaningless. And that's okay, at least for me: It's the humor that counts in this type of movies.David Zukcer has managed to milk everything from the movie, it is as funny as it could be. I can't see any way to improved the film, it has gags for everyone, be them fast sight gags or verbal juggling, or even slap stick comedy. The bests scenes are, when someone is doing something seemingly important while Drebin or some else goofs up in the background, leading up in sheer stupidity and situations so absurd, that you just cannot help but to laugh

reviews.review_title: A hilarious fun-fest that likely left many leaving the theater howling with laughter!
reviews.content: What is there to say about this film? Fresh from the days of Police Squad!, Leslie Nielsen stars in this film about a cop named Frank Drebin getting clues about something with the Queen... in a humorous way! However all of this leads up to some antics at a baseball game. His poor friend Nordberg got into an accident, causing him to be injured throughout the film. Leslie Nielsen, outside of Airplane!, is at his gold here. He handles each and every scene oh so well. There was hardly a moment when he made a joke that I didn't laugh at it. And him being a white haired gentlemen that was getting elderly made it even more hilarious. Unfortunately the Queen doesn't play the Queen here. Instead it's Jeannette Charles, who does do a rather good act of her. I loved how she was so stuffy throughout the entire movie, politely waving and being highly disgusted by mild things. Perhaps one of the funniest moments in the entire flick was when Frank ended up taking the role of Enrico Pallazzo and started singing the National Anthem in a grating tone and incorrect lyrics. That scene was absolutely hilarious! But not nearly as hilarious as when the woman was trying to make a speech, and after Frank drank some cups of water he left his microphone on making his peeing audible during the entire thing. All in all, I must say that this was one of the funniest movies I have ever seen. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves comedy movies such as this!

reviews.review_title: Innovative comedy spoofing inept high profile police work
reviews.content: This is a rather refreshing 'new kind of comedy', with an original premise: Have a law-man who is clearly 'not with it' go on a crime-fighting spree, critically injuring innocent people as he goes, only to end up catching the bad guys (by accident or by mistake), receiving top recognition for his fine work. You must see this sort of bizarre non-sense to believe it! When Police Sergeant Frank Drebin (played by Leslie Nielsen) first appeared on American TV screens back in about 1980, we weren't quite ready for the humor that came "without a cuing laugh track". A few years later "The Naked Gun" gave us another chance. This time it "took"! The one-liners and come backs in this film are hilarious, as the clumsy Drebin "always gets his man". Pricilla Presley is wonderful as the "agent for the enemy" who soon becomes Drebin's love interest.The scenes where fellow police officer Nuremberg (played by O.J. Simpson) repeatedly gets brutally injured (to roaring laughter from the audience) have been criticized as racist. Some of the "double entendre" is a bit risqué for kids, but otherwise this is fun for any age audience.
One of the funniest films of the 80s and still a timeless classic. So funny from start to the end and i can still laugh my ass off watching it for the 100th time.

The Naked Gun is a spoof of most cop movies from any decade. In it, a bumbling detective uncovers a plot made by a big business man to murder the Queen of England at the World Series with a device that can control people's minds. It is a completely absurd comedy the likes of Airplane!, and anybody with a taste for hilarious parody will enjoy it.The plot of the movie is pretty good. It is mainly a spoof of detective movies from the 50s, what with the confident detective who narrates and speaks in the macho tone. Unfortunately, this detective is so clueless that everything he does is a major screw up. The humour in this movie isn't really intelligent humour. It's stupid humour that is so ridiculous it's funny. I can't really think of much else to say besides this movie is hilarious. It features one of my favourite kinds of humour, and that's word gags. Most of the jokes come from the way people speak to each other rather than visually.Leslie Nielsen is a great comedian, and this movie is no exception. The other actors in the film are good as well, including Percilla Presley and Ricardo Montalbon.Overall, this is a classic comedy I would recommend to anybody who needs a good laugh.8/10

nice beaver!I had it stuffedCracks me up every time. I love this movie 25 years after I'd first seen it as a 12 year old. Funny how more jokes come out every time I watch. It is quite deep for a silly comedy, and it's a certain sign of a masterpiece

reviews.review_title: the funniest movie of alltime, classic
reviews.content: i didn't really rate airplane the first time i saw it, but i did love leslie nielsen in it, i thought he was by far the funniest thing about it. so i saw the naked gun and i loved it, it is the funniest movie of alltime period, leslie nielsen as frank drebin is legendary and is one of the best characters of cinema period, a tad more aware than he was in police squad but just as funny, leslie nielsen really is a joy to watch hear, and it really will have you rolling on the floor, it isn't worth going into the plot trust me, but thats not what makes these kinds of movies, trust me the naked gun is the funniest comedy of alltime period and will always be.

reviews.review_title: The Naked Gun is one of the funniest movies ever!!!!
reviews.content: Minor SpoilersI just laugh at this movie ever time I see it which I have seen this alot! Everything is so funny. I don`t know what part is funnier whether its when Nielson is in Ricardo`s room playing with the rare pen and the fish or when he is at the press conference or when he is up on the siding of the building or could it be the beginning of the film or could it be the great baseball game? Like I said this movie is so funny.There are two sequels to the Naked Gun but to ME this is the best of the three. If you need a good laugh or cheer someone up this is the movie to watch!
